27 Dresses is formulaic, predictable and unoriginal, but romantic comedies would be burned at the stake if they didn't follow the strict guidelines above - it's almost kinda fun seeing it hit all of its marks.
The characters are so uneven it feels like two different movies awkwardly fused together.
The horror genre is not often known for its subtlety, but The Orphanage proves that sometimes it's more satisfying to squirm in your seat than it is to jump out of it.
Lars And The Real Girl is a film without compare, about as far removed from conventional comedy as it's possible to be.
Think Mean Girls making out with Teen Wolf on the set of The Faculty. Or something.
Hancock is what happens when you have talented people working on quality material: it's really a no-brainer that it works so well.
Even with elbow room to spare, the series' linchpin saga will still leave you wanting more... of the Futurama of old.
movie_title: Futurama: Into the Wild Green Yonder (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Mist is a creature feature in which the monsters are almost incidental, but the panic and fear-mongering that comes with the territory is what ultimately causes the most chaos.
Like a big gay Terminator, Mamma Mia! will track down your cynicism and blast it into smithereens: it absolutely will not stop, ever, until you're having fun.
About as predictable as socks under the tree.

Quarantine is symptomatic of a broken industry; one that would rather remake a perfectly good foreign language film with nice, safe, recognisable American faces rather than plough any money into original concepts.

Some may tire of Smith's template of toilet humour and tits, but to others, those very same qualities are a guarantee of entertainment. Love him or hate him, Kevin Smith isn't afraid to hit new lows to get new laughs.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The sole high point? 3D tits. The porn industry is going to love this technology, presuming you don't mind wearing stupid dark glasses while masturbating.
See you next year, I guess. Sigh.
A comedy so stupid, it doesn't realise it's a comedy. If intelligence is relative, then ignorance is bliss.
At times, you feel you can see the character - and by proxy the writers - actually thinking, "So what now?"
The Rocker is more Keane than Keith Moon: slow, safe and about as edgy as a tangerine.
A murky, muddled, miserable mess, Righteous Kill spends 101 minutes failing to achieve what Heat managed in just six.
What we have is a comedy that's not that great, a romance that's not that convincing and a movie that's sadly not that special. Now that's how you lose friends and alienate people.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tropic Thunder is an easy film to enjoy. It appeals to the basest levels of humour without patronising its audience, while pricking the pomposity of the movie industry without going too 'meta' - this is far from self-fellation.
Given that cast, crew and audience were and will be baked throughout, Pineapple Express just about earns itself a pass.
Good news, everybody!

At six foot plus, with his hair-plug mullet and his ice-white teeth, Cage sticks out like a sore thumb among the tiny Thai citizens, making for the most conspicuous hitman since Agent 47 rocked the bald head 'n' barcode combination.
Just get comfortable, sit back and smile at the slaughter - unlike Funny Games, at least this is bloodshed you can enjoy.
It's a film of many firsts, but few of them positive: for the first time in history, we have a Star Wars film that you won't love or hate, but one about which you just won't care less either way.
Even the apologists will have to admit that this is not the X-Files movie they'd hoped for.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Baby Mama is far more funny than it has any right to be and boasts a dynamite pairing that shows plenty of promise for the future: here's hoping Fey and Poehler pick something a little less formulaic for their next project.

It's not just the best Batman film ever. It's not just the best superhero movie ever. It's more than a money-spinner, a franchise, a comic-book cash-in. The Dark Knight is a stunning piece of work that deserves every word of praise spoken about it.
Pick any 24th of a second, frame it and you could hang it on a museum wall.
Emmerich favours hoisting his camera high and dry to give audiences the best panoramic view, but it removes all tension from proceedings - you're always at a safe distance.
Martha Marcy May Marlene might not have campaign funding or grandstanding performances, but it has heart and soul, two qualities which are slowly corrupted throughout for your viewing pleasure.
Weird for the sake of weird? Definitely. A work of art? Maybe. Genius? Hardly. But be sure of one thing: this is most certainly a box that's worth peeking into.

Unflinchingly nasty, graphic and gut-wrenchingly powerful, Snowtown is a film that dares you to look away, but compels you to keep watching. As portraits of serial killers go, this deserves to be hung on the wall next to Henry.
Arguably Spielberg's most out-and-out fun movie since Jurassic Park.
Juggling moments of pitch black humour and disturbingly tense scenes of abuse, Sleeping Beauty has a queasy, mismatched tone that underscores an uneven, elliptical movie.
Tyrannosaur is cinema that scars the soul - you'll only want to see it once, but once is enough.
No matter how old or cynical I get, part of me will always be that same 12-year-old boy, sat in rapture, watching dinosaurs rule the world.
It'll make you laugh, it'll make you'll frown, it might even make you cry, but mostly it'll just make you want to have sex with Ryan Gosling.
Warrior reveals itself to be more than just a brainless slugger - like the best boxing movies, it's able to utterly wrap you up in the moment and have you punching the air come its conclusion.
Neither overblown action movie or intimate character study, Drive is somewhere in between - my approximation of "an arthouse Fast & Furious" wasn't too wide of the mark after all.

I could spend hours talking about how fantastic The Artist is; how sublime Dujardin and Bérénice Bejo are; how natural their movements and expressions are; how perfect the score is - oh, the score, so expressive and lively and jovial and magical.
Remake or not, if you're going to make a vampire movie in 2011, you'd better at least try to do something original. Something. Anything.
It's testament to the 2000 original that there's still so much mileage left in the 'death is coming for you' concept 11 years later.
I couldn't help but feel the film was lent shades of colour by the book; colour that simply doesn't exist on the screen. I projected 435 pages of joy onto a film that probably didn't deserve it.
Patchy, if enjoyable in parts, but nowhere near as awesome as that title suggests it should be.
Super 8 is undoubtedly one of the more robust summer blockbusters of the year, with enough momentum to get it over the finish line before you start asking more questions of it.
Even next to Thor, a movie about a space god with a magic hammer, Captain America: The First Avenger was always going to be one of Marvel's trickiest properties to do justice to.
It's fair to say that everyone will get at least something out of this film.
If you like mindless spectacle, this is undoubtedly the frontrunner so far this year.
There's a full spectrum of emotions on show: how many comedies with a gag involving projectile vomit and diarrhoea can say that?
Kill List is bravura filmmaking - an impeccable guide on how to build tension and character without sacrificing story.
Shame is a snapshot of a tumultuous life, shot without judgement and censure - the fascinating story of a man who seemingly has everything and nothing both at once.
A hugely enjoyable, unpredictable thriller that never forgets to be fun first and foremost.
Don't let the fact that it's different - or unadulterated bullshit of the highest order - put you off a story that, in truth, is more interesting than it is wholly entertaining or accurate.
Delightfully silly, slathered with gore and yes, even touching at times, Shaun Of The Dead should at the very least highlight Wright and Pegg as the British comedic force to watch for the future.
Like Family Guy, Ted's obsession with fame, celebrity and brainless sight gags means it's content being merely funny now but forgettable in the long term.
One of those romantic comedies that spends too much time unnecessarily creating drama for its characters.
Brave strives above all else to make an emotional connection, and boy does it connect: a hugely atmospheric fairytale of old, it's Pixar's most mature movie to date.

The Raid is a martial arts movie of such ferocious pace, you'll swear you're watching it on the wrong speed. A shaken-up energy drink of a movie, once unleashed it fizzes out of the can, leaving you adrenalized - and sticky.

The Dictator is comedy at its broadest, but underneath the 'hilarious' beard and predictable September 11th gags lies a sharp script that attempts to aim lowbrow and highbrow at the same time - and almost pulls it off.
American Pie: Reunion does exactly what's expected of it, no more, no less - it's less a fresh slice of pie and more of a re-bake.
Perhaps more interesting than outright entertaining, Hesher is something of an acquired taste.
It's such a soul-sucking, humourless mess of technobabble and gobble-de-gook, I'm pretty sure sitting through it made me a Scientologist or something.

A lousier adventure movie you won't find this year: 10,000 B.C. belongs, if not back in the stone age, then at least back in the mid '90s, where this sort of mindless, effects-driven drivel is best left.

Lacking the over-polished zing of Juno or the heft of either of Reitman's previous offerings, Young Adult is nonetheless an interesting pseudo-comedy that dares to add depth to its characters instead of just having them be assholes for laughs.
There is no better way to summarise the ways in which Clint Eastwood's Hoover biopic fails: J. Edgar is just boring. It just is. It looks boring, it sounds boring, it feels boring, it IS boring.

It's about as manipulative a film has Steven Spielberg has ever made - a movie that's been custom-designed from the ground up to play a sad harp solo on the heartstrings; a story cynically told to invoke as many tears as possible.
All of Looper's ideas, elements and actions loop back on themselves to create a thrilling, fascinating and fiercely imaginative head-scratcher that's undoubtedly the best sci-fi of 2012.
Another Earth occasionally slips into chin-stroking pretention, but it flies the flags for indies with ideas bigger than their budgets.
Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol is the kind of lean, mean, fearless action movie that chugs along at such a high tempo, you realise when leaving the cinema that you're actually running.
50/50 is smartly written and well acted enough to have you fully invested once it's time to find out if those titular odds come good.
You can't take your eyes off it - it's like watching the butchest float on the Gay Pride parade crash in super slow-motion HD.
Arthur Christmas will snuggle you up into a big, hearty festive cuddle and refuse to put you down until you've hugged it back.
Mother's Day is just as forgettable as whatever day Mother's Day actually is.
Crass, charmless and not especially funny, Bad Teacher is like a school kid trying to be cool.
The Hangover: Part II shows the writers have absolutely no faith in their characters or their own ability to take them somewhere new.
Teenage assassin trained as a killing machine since birth? Unless your movie has Nicolas Cage dressed like Batman with a paedo-tache, you're fighting a losing battle from the start.

The Girl Who Kicked The Hornet's Nest doesn't exactly give the Millennium trilogy the explosive send-off it deserves, and stacked against the other two movies in the series, it's perhaps the weakest story of the three.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Social Network may not turn out to be the definitive movie made about the plugged-in generation, but it's a pretty good start.
As a defeated Phoenix cleanses himself in the waters of Panama at the movie's climax, ultimately you're left asking the same question you were wondering when you went in: why should I care?
The very definition of 'switch your brain off' entertainment.
Frankly, us geeks have never had it so good: Scott Pilgrim Vs The World is modern cinema at its most exciting, and it belongs to us.

The action scenes are huge and excessively violent on a scale not seen since the closing scenes of Commando. At one point, in the absence of any buildings to detonate or ammunition depots to destroy, I think I saw an explosion explode.
A good old-fashioned bad action movie; the type the eighties used to churn out on a regular basis.
The jury's still out on Brand as a leading man, at least on this evidence, but chances are you won't find a vehicle better suited to his comic sensibilities than this one.

Gyllenhaal might have seemed like an odd choice to top-line an action flick, given his indie leanings and wet noodle persona, but he's surprisingly tolerable as Dastan; a parkour-obsessed oik who grows into an abs-solutely un-flabulous warrior.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: By rights, a superhero sequel should be darker, more intense and more dangerous, but Favreau is happy just to stay cool. That's all Iron Man's job has ever been, and frankly, that's fine by me.
Date Night is only ever moderately funny; partially entertaining; quite exciting. It bears the mark of a cinematic no-mark; a bland director whose cast members deserve way better than him.

The period setting has been captured to a tee; it's all red bricks, ghastly wallpaper, casual racism and cut-glass fruitbowls. Everything is viewed through a haze of cigarette smoke. It's little wonder the kids want out.
If you want to get serious, you could say that Kick-Ass is the movie that could finally drag comic-books into the credible mainstream. But being serious is to miss the point of Kick-Ass completely.
A clever story of murder and mystery interspersed with various acts of cyber-crime and corporate intrigue, it's the most refreshing thriller in recent memory.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Time to take some of Lewis Carroll's advice, Tim: eat me.
There is a better movie in here, lost in the edit and screaming to get out, but unfortunately, this Wolfman is howling at a moon that's only half-full.

The Road is a highly emotional, involving, palm-sweatingly tense movie that will scar you for life if you let it. Exhausting to watch but oddly exhilirating to experience, it's a film you'll watch once but will never forget.

That Daybreakers biggest problem is that there isn't enough of it should tell you enough: watching it provides short-term entertainment, but like those voracious bloodsuckers, it'll just leave you wanting more.
Piercing the hype, Avatar may not be a "game changer", but I'll be damned if the game didn't just get a hell of a lot more interesting from here on in.
Catfish is a unique documentary - like Capturing The Friedmans, it starts as one thing and mutates into a completely different, terrifying animal halfway through.

Diverting enough as a visual curio, and boasting a extremely pleasant soundtrack a la Yann Tiersen's score for Amelie, Bunny And The Bull has a surplus of style but little in the way of real substance.
Monsters asks greater questions of its audience than the usual special effects yawn-fests.
127 Hours asks a big question of its audience: could you do what Aron Ralston does when it came down to it?
A revenge flick that's just about as uncompromising as anything I've seen come out of Asia in the last decade or so.
Brutal? Funny? Clever? You get the feeling that maybe, just maybe, Randy would have approved after all.
Rubber won't be everyone's cup of tea, but as curios go, it's among the more watchable movies about killer tyres you're likely to see this year.
If it wasn't executed with such panache it would probably qualify as one of the dumbest movies of 2011.
Just the worst, most cliché-ridden bunch of faceless cannon fodder you've ever had the misfortune to watch die.
It's funny, sad, touching and charming; a film that's in turns joyously ridiculous yet on occasion hits devastatingly close to home.

The Adjustment Bureau does sadly descend into science-fiction nonsense after a bold start, but it's always enjoyable and you never lose sight of what's at stake thanks to excellent character work from Damon and Blunt.
Acting opposite Ashton Kutcher is the equivalent of dropping down a year in school for someone like Natalie Portman.
Drive Angry is very obviously Nicolas Cage embracing his own ridiculousness, or - in language invented by Bad Lieutenant director Werner Herzog - "releasing the pigs".
Animal Kingdom is frequently shocking - not just because it makes Air Supply's 'I'm All Out Of Love' sound cool.
Paul is probably the closest thing to Spaced that Pegg and Frost have made since Edgar Wright closed the book on Tim & Daisy.
You can practically feel comedy facepalming itself.
It's a continuing clash between laughably poor acting and ultra-serious brow-furrowing that renders Sanctum unintentionally hilarious, thereby deflating it completely.
Rabbit Hole is hardly what you'd call a date movie, and it's difficult to see what kind of audiences it'd appeal to outside of awards season chin-strokers.
Before long, the afterlife starts to sound pretty damn appealing.
Though it touches on a number of genres and encapsulates several themes, Black Swan is best viewed as a horror movie - a slow creep into insanity that's touching and terrifying in equal measure.
The Dilemma is quite enjoyable until its characters stop behaving like rational adults and start acting like they've just realised they've got a film to finish.
A pleasingly average superhero movie whose greatest triumph is avoiding disaster.

It's not quite the world-beating effort the British film press might have you thinking it is, but it's a perfectly functional, frequently enjoyable biopic that knows the right buttons to push and has all the right people pushing them.

The Next Three Days is kind of a throwback to the classic action movies Hollywood put out in the mid-nineties - the 'one man versus the world' era of thrillers, in which lantern-jawed heroes fight to save their family against improbable odds
Not just a movie but an event in its own right, Grindhouse is simply unmissable in its complete form.
Pray that this is a franchise that's dead for good this time.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Semi-Pro will likely leave its star with a sore throat and bruised pride but a bulging wallet nonetheless: it's possibly the first movie ever to be less funny than the products it advertises.
Strip out the gags, the explosions and the posturing, and you see The Expendables 3 for what it really is: a bunch of knackered old men pandering to teenagers. Grim.
Nine years after the pages first turned on Sin City, and with three major parts recast, this Dame To Kill For is sashaying into town long after everyone has lost interest.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's scary, but it's also entertainment. It's scarentertainment. (That's awful. Forget I wrote that).
Sex Tape is too busy blowing smoke up Apple's rear port to make any meaningful comment on the testy relationship between intimacy and technology.
If Gone Girl's first half is a forensic dissection of a marriage that cuts like an autopsy, the second half sees the coroners cut loose, chucking guts around for fun.
It aged me. I felt like my Dad trying to comprehend a Tamagotchi.
This iteration of pop culture's most idiotic quartet has the IQ of a cheese pizza but it's not a total cowabungle.
Fury succeeds in what it sets out to do - convince you that heroism is born out of horror.
If this represents just 10% of Luc Besson's creative potency, the mind boggles at what he could achieve at full capacity.
A glacial, passive drama where true emotions seethe beneath a surface of calm - until they can be contained no more.
All the talk of Kubrick and 2001 is light years off the mark: Interstellar is the kind of space odyssey that has only shameless, monolothic entertainment on the agenda.
By the closing credits you too will share the characters' grief, solemnly mourning 137 minutes you'll never get back. Insufferable.
There's a sense here of making hay while the sun shines: just as the characters wing their way through their ill-conceived plan with a wink and a smile, so do the filmmakers.
The best part in the best movie trilogy of all time.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang is notable for many things. Firstly, the pairing of Downey Jr. and Kilmer is absolutely inspired.
Not many films can capture electricity and bottle it, but Damien Chazelle is a conductor par excellence. If the final scene doesn't move you in every sense, you're a corpse.
In a nutshell: Judged on its own merits, Whiplash is superb: slick, authentic and infectious.
As exhausting as it is exhilarating, Big Hero 6 feels like an animation in step with an ever-changing world.
Gyllenhaal has done a magnificent job transforming himself inwards, thinning out those film star looks until he resembles an unmasked Scooby Doo villain.
Guardians Of The Galaxy is one of Marvel's best films simply because it doesn't really feel like it's part of the Marvel universe at all.
A B-movie with A-grade ambitions and ideas way above its station, The Purge series feels like an incredible concept in search of filmmakers with equally high aspirations.
A third Apes movie featuring no human characters would be the perfect evolution for a thrilling series that has itself evolved way beyond reasonable expectations.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: All Is Lost is a movie that is understated, yet still manages to play out on a staggeringly huge canvas; the personal and the universal one and the same.
With Greengrass an expert navigator of choppy waters and Hanks the assured hand at the wheel, Captain Phillips is one of the year's most thrilling cinematic voyages.
Though Don Jon succeeds in being funny at every turn, it is less successful in being a movie with something important to say.
Though it uses some spotty logic and galactic-sized plot contrivances to get it over the finish line, Thor: The Dark World is never less than breathlessly entertaining.
Frustratingly directionless and unconcerned with detail, but fans of the writer will feel right at home wallowing through fresh reams of his trademark bleak prose.
Required to run the gamut from sympathetic, troubled victim of circumstance to sweaty, coke-fuelled rage monster, McAvoy is a horrifically enjoyable revelation.
Spend three hours on Scorsese's Wall Street, and he'll have you convinced: greed isn't just good - it's great.
The world has changed since Tom Clancy's heyday - cinema doesn't need Jack Ryan any more.
Creatively bereft and poorly cast, this Jack Ryan is sadly one spy who blends into the crowd a little too easily.
As remakes go, this is no RoboCop-out. Sleek though it may be, it's not hard to imagine how much better a version for adults would have been.
I could honestly stare at Nick Frost's face for hours: he is literally a human teddy bear.
It is crucial that a film of this genre can convince you it is smarter than you are. Non-Stop fails, but makes an admirable effort to distract you with silliness.
Under The Skin finds grace even in moments of raw horror, composed by a filmmaker who can legitimately call himself a master of the art.
It offers no easy answers and takes no sides: the result is one of the most engrossing, exciting and explosive prison films the UK has ever produced.
You'll see nothing Ridley Scott didn't do better a decade ago and nothing 300: Rise Of An Empire didn't do with more style six weeks ago.
Show a non-football fan Next Goal Wins, and I guarantee that by the final whistle they'll have a new-found appreciation for the beautiful game.
Godzilla stands tall in the modern pantheon of monster movies: a no-nonsense beast that makes his 90s counterpart look like a bogey with legs.
It's taut, twisted and blackly funny in ways that only movies in which Tom Cruise gets crushed under the wheel of a truck can be.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Boyhood is an astonishing body of work: a unique cinematic experience that condenses over a decade of life into three blissful hours. The kind of movie you want to swim in.
Kingsman is an unashamedly entertaining spy movie that'd likely raise Roger Moore's eyebrow into the stratosphere.
It's one of the best films of the year so far.
There's a slinky, Soderbergh vibe in the DNA here; Focus feels like it's pitched somewhere between Out Of Sight and Ocean's Eleven.
This is horror boiled down to its bones.
Logan, and Jackman, know you can't secure a legacy by leaving a door open.
A fascinating yet flawed study of modern feminism.
I want to personally high five every graphic designer and digital artist who pulled extra shifts and worked weekends on this movie.
The moves are telegraphed way in advance, like idiots playing chess, but you always get your money from the play set
At long last, the Alien franchise has evolved.
Think a female Michael Clayton. It's Michelle Clayton.
The whole movie is a weird, unsettling mix of juvenile storytelling and military fetishism, but it never fails to entertain, even if for the wrong reasons.
Perhaps this is a fitting end to a franchise that had absolutely no right to produce movies as good as it did.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most relentlessly intense, gut-churning portrayals of escalating madness ever captured on screen.
An occasionally inventive action flick that is nonetheless torpedoed by an off-colour joke so brazen and shameless it defies belief.
Fully fleshed out with a fierce imagination and sharp good looks, it doesn't matter if Blade Runner 2049 is a replica of an original model - it's even better than the real thing.
An extremely broad Nordic noir parody, or at the very least a join-the-dots handbook for the genre impaired: Scandinavian Crime Drama for Dummies.
Pathos and charm required from original LEGO Movie, not sold separately.
Smart, slick and - thanks to a towering Jessica Chastain performance - more than a bit sexy
It wasn't evil aliens that defeated the Justice League: it was facial hair.
Soundtracked by an authentic score, the movie has an electric rhythmicality; every scene bounces as if dancing to the beat of its own drum.
Characters skate around the truth with almost as much dexterity as they do the ice rink
Movies that burn through this much bluster usually struggle to sustain interest, but Mom & Dad is just practicing what it preaches: at 83 minutes long, it dies before it gets old.
Quick and to the point when it comes to delivering scares.
A Shutter Island horror knock-off that's not scary, starring the supermarket own-brand Leonardo DiCaprio, that's at least an hour too long.
Like a game of online poker, the thrills in Runner Runner come in small increments. Pretty but vacant, it's unremarkable and entirely forgettable.
Shyamalan has managed to deliver a fiercely effective, ferociously funny and genuinely gory horror movie, all without relying on a last act rug-pull.
Can't decide if it's a blockbuster or a character piece and ends up being neither.
Diesel & Statham test each other's manhood by playing a game of car chicken, smashing into each other at maximum velocity in a tunnel - Furious 7 is the Large Hardon Collider.
You spend the entire movie willing the earth to open up beneath their characters' feet and swallow them for the good of humankind.
Spy won't go down as a classic, but it is a perfectly serviceable comedy that's well cast, sharply written and furthers the feminist cause without even making it a thing.
Films like Jurassic World are not just the reason why we go to the movies, they're the reason movies stay with us after we leave.
Terminator Genisys is literally a movie that devotes more time to explaining how characters source their trousers than it does explaining their goals.
What was the funniest bit? The Minions.
The movie's fuse stays lit for a good 90 minutes, but sadly it fizzles out come the disappointing climax.
Boyle's portrait of the Apple legend is a lively affair that has you convinced of one man's genius, although we're guessing that man wasn't supposed to be Aaron Sorkin.
Deadpool is the 'edgy' stand-up hired to play the corporate gig: make the company laugh, but don't make the company mad.
A pseudo-documentary dressed up like a human interest ensemble when it should have felt more like a supervillain heist movie.
It is its own cinematic zooniverse.
Arguably the movie that the previous 12 Marvel adventures have all been working towards
X-Men: Apocalypse is a clumsy comic-book caricature. There are literally sequences in this movie that were predicted in Deadpool.
It trades a nice line in the 'big dumb fun' brand of stupidity, instead of the 'hound Damon Lindelof off Twitter' variety.
We're now at a point in the history of animation where animators can tell a joke with a facial expression shared between a fish and a cephalopod.
They say each generation deserves their own version of a classic story, and Magnificent 7 is the version this generation deserves: polished but still remarkably unremarkable.
An inward-looking comedy that's not afraid to poke fun at its country's own foibles but still manages to feel like a celebration of life on a little island.
The worst thing you can say about Doctor Strange is that it doesn't aim high enough.
A touch too familiar to qualify as a modern classic, Moana is a relentlessly entertaining spectacle rooted in authenticity with a talent pool so deep you can swim in it.
xXx: Return Of Xander Cage is very much an old person's idea of what they think young people want to watch.
In poker terms, Runner Runner is the player who wins an average stack of chips, bets moderately, cashes out even and leaves before the game gets interesting.
Every time Luc Besson uses a bullet in a body as a punchline, a real joke somewhere out in the wild dies.
Sweet, witty and exquisitely observed, In A World... sees the emergence of an exciting talent: any agents looking for a new triple threat should ring that Bell.
The first thing you see in Saw IV is Jigsaw's balls. A sign of things to come? Most definitely.
Up there with Finding Nemo and Monsters Inc. as one of Pixar's best creature features.
Anyone can trace a Picasso.

Far from being a spoof on the genre, Shoot 'Em Up is an action movie with the flab removed - with no more than maybe ten minutes of exposition, you're left with a series of interconnecting money shots, each one more gooey than the last.

Elevated above the usual fare by an engaging and complex relationship between its two stars, 3:10 To Yuma would be a thoroughly entertaining two hours whatever the genre - the Western setting is almost a bonus.
Unfortunately, what starts out as a rounded and intelligent thriller soon turns up the silly for an OTT finale that betrays the tense and well-plotted build-up.
It's a movie with heart and with balls, and it knows when to use each of them.
Like shacking up with a cheap hooker in a moderately priced hotel, 1408 delivers dirty thrills with few frills.

It's a simple tale about two horny kids not only on a quest for vodka, beer and sticky fumbling, but they're looking to find themselves in the process. I'll be damned if there's many people left in the cinema afterwards who won't relate to that.
I would honestly rather watch the Holocaust In Colour than sit through this again.
As an anomaly, a curio, even as half a movie, it's a winner. As a stand-alone feature, it struggles to stand up to close scrutiny.
Rush falls short of greatness due to a final layer of artifice lacquered over the screenplay: that's the Peter Morgan difference.
It really is a crushing disappointment to report that The Simpsons Movie is merely average by its own lofty standards.
Transformers leaves very few blocks left un-busted.
Ultimately, a passable new Die Hard movie is more than anyone of us ever really expected, and that in itself is worth a jolly old Yippee-Ki-Ay.
